p: In adult animals, SBV mostly causes subclinical infections; however, occasionally, especially in cattle, clinical signs of fever, diarrhea and a reduction in milk yield are not uncommon [ 1]. In transplacental infections, congenital CNS and musculoskeletal malformations, such as the AG-HE syndrome, aplasia or hypoplasia of the cerebrum or cerebellum and hydranencephaly are observed [ 33, 45, 49]. Virological and/or serological diagnosis is needed to confirm suspicion of SBV infection because of similarities between clinical features of SBV and other ruminant virus infections [ 33].
